title: 103_hr2632
content: SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes $103,000,000 for salaries and expenses in fiscal year 1994 from the Patent and Trademark Office Fee Surcharge Fund. The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes $103,000,000 for necessary expenses in fiscal year 1994, derived from the Patent and Trademark Office Fee Surcharge Fund. Additionally, fees collected under title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946 will be made available to the Patent and Trademark Office for fiscal year 1994. SEC. 3. Amounts appropriated under this Act may remain available until expended. SEC. 4. The fee for filing a trademark registration application will be $245, effective upon enactment, with any fee adjustments not effective before October 1, 1994. SEC. 5. Interim patent extensions. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code is amended to include provisions for extending the regulatory review period for patents under certain circumstances. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code is amended to allow for interim extensions of the patent term if regulatory review periods may extend beyond the expiration date. The owner or its agent may apply for an interim extension of a patent term if regulatory review periods go beyond the patent expiration date. The application must include details of the product under review, the relevant federal statute, and the patent being extended. The application for an interim patent extension must include details of the product under regulatory review, the relevant federal statute, the patent being extended, and activities undertaken during the review period. The application for an interim patent extension must include details of the product under regulatory review, relevant federal statute, patent being extended, activities undertaken during the review period, and information required by the Commissioner for determining eligibility for extension. The Commissioner may grant an interim extension for a patent eligible for extension under certain conditions, including permission to market the product commercially. The owner of the patent can apply for this extension. The Commissioner may grant an interim extension for a patent eligible for extension under certain conditions, including permission to market the product commercially. The owner of record of a patent, or its agent, may apply for subsequent interim extensions, with a limit of 4 extensions except for specific cases where only 1 extension is allowed. Each subsequent application must be made 60 days before the current extension expires. Each subsequent interim extension under this paragraph must be applied for 60 days before the current extension expires. The certificate of interim extension is recorded in the patent file and considered part of the original patent. Each subsequent interim extension must be applied for 60 days before the current extension expires and recorded in the patent file. The extension terminates 60 days after the product receives permission for commercial marketing or use. The patent extension can be further extended for up to 5 years from the original expiration date if the applicant notifies the Commissioner and submits additional information within the 60-day period after receiving permission for commercial marketing or use. The patent can be further extended for up to 5 years from the original expiration date or from the date of product approval for commercial use. During the extension period, the rights are limited to the use under regulatory review. During the interim extension period, patent rights are limited to the specific uses or methods of manufacturing that are under regulatory review for the product involved. SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to clarify and update various subsections regarding rights and provisions. SEC. 7. PATENT TERM EXTENSIONS FOR AMERICAN LEGION. The design patents for the badges of the American Legion, American Legion Women's Auxiliary, and Sons of the American Legion are renewed and extended for 14 years with all rights and privileges. The design patents for the badges of the American Legion Women's Auxiliary and Sons of the American Legion are renewed and extended for 14 years with all rights and privileges. SEC. 8. INTERVENING RIGHTS. The renewals and extensions of patents under section 6 will not infringe on any use of the patent's subject matter that began after the patent expired but before the enactment of this Act.
